nodes.name: Machine Learning
nodes.description: The study of algorithms and statistical models that computer systems use to perform specific tasks without explicit instructions.

nodes.name: Natural Language Processing
nodes.description: The ability of a computer program to understand human language as it is spoken.

nodes.name: Computer Vision
nodes.description: The field of computer science that focuses on replicating aspects of human vision using computer algorithms and hardware.

nodes.name: Expert Systems
nodes.description: Computer-based systems that emulate the decision-making ability of a human expert.

nodes.name: Knowledge Representation
nodes.description: The study of how knowledge can be represented and manipulated by computers.

nodes.name: Robotics
nodes.description: The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots.

nodes.name: Supervised Learning
nodes.description: A type of machine learning where an algorithm learns from labeled data to make predictions or decisions.

nodes.name: Unsupervised Learning
nodes.description: A type of machine learning where an algorithm learns patterns from unlabeled data without any specific target variable.

nodes.name: Semi-Supervised Learning
nodes.description: A type of machine learning where an algorithm learns from a combination of labeled and unlabeled data.

nodes.name: Reinforcement Learning
nodes.description: A type of machine learning where an agent learns to interact with an environment and receives rewards or punishments based on its actions.

nodes.name: Deep Learning
nodes.description: A subfield of machine learning that focuses on neural networks with multiple hidden layers.

nodes.name: Neural Networks
nodes.description: A type of machine learning model inspired by the structure and functioning of the human brain.

nodes.name: Convolutional Neural Networks
nodes.description: A type of neural network commonly used for image recognition and processing tasks.

nodes.name: Recurrent Neural Networks
nodes.description: A type of neural network commonly used for sequential data processing.

nodes.name: Generative Adversarial Networks
nodes.description: A type of neural network architecture that consists of two networks: a generator and a discriminator, which compete with each other to improve the overall model.

nodes.name: Decision Trees
nodes.description: A type of machine learning model that uses tree-like graphs to make decisions or predictions.

nodes.name: Tokenization
nodes.description: The process of breaking text into individual units called tokens.

nodes.name: Text Normalization
nodes.description: The process of transforming text into a standard form, such as converting all text to lowercase or removing punctuation.

nodes.name: Stop Word Removal
nodes.description: The process of removing commonly occurring words that do not carry significant meaning, such as 'the', 'is', 'and', etc.

nodes.name: Part-of-Speech Tagging
nodes.description: The process of assigning grammatical tags to words based on their role in a sentence, such as noun, verb, adjective, etc.

nodes.name: Named Entity Recognition
nodes.description: The process of identifying and classifying named entities in text, such as person names, organization names, location names, etc.

nodes.name: Sentiment Analysis
nodes.description: The process of determining the sentiment or emotion expressed in a piece of text, such as positive, negative, or neutral.

nodes.name: Topic Modeling
nodes.description: The process of automatically discovering topics or themes in a collection of documents.

nodes.name: Text Classification
nodes.description: The process of assigning predefined categories or labels to text based on its content, such as spam detection or sentiment classification.

nodes.name: Language Generation
nodes.description: The process of generating human-like text using computational models, such as chatbots or language translation systems.

nodes.name: Machine Translation
nodes.description: The process of automatically translating text from one language to another, often using statistical or neural machine translation models.

nodes.name: Image Processing
nodes.description: The study and application of techniques for enhancing, analyzing, and manipulating images.

nodes.name: Image Segmentation
nodes.description: The process of partitioning an image into multiple segments to simplify the representation of an image into meaningful regions.

nodes.name: Object Detection
nodes.description: The task of identifying and localizing objects in an image or video.

nodes.name: Object Recognition
nodes.description: The process of identifying and classifying objects in an image or video.

nodes.name: Image Classification
nodes.description: The task of assigning a label or class to an image based on its content.

nodes.name: Feature Extraction
nodes.description: The process of obtaining relevant and meaningful information from images to represent them in a more compact form.

nodes.name: Object Tracking
nodes.description: The task of tracking the motion and trajectory of objects in a sequence of images or videos.

nodes.name: Depth Estimation
nodes.description: The process of determining the distance of objects from a camera or sensor using image or video data.

nodes.name: Pose Estimation
nodes.description: The task of determining the position and orientation of objects in an image or video.

nodes.name: Image Registration
nodes.description: The process of aligning two or more images to perform comparison or analysis.

nodes.name: Inference Engine
nodes.description: The component of an expert system that uses logical rules and facts to draw conclusions and make inferences.

nodes.name: Knowledge Base
nodes.description: The component of an expert system that stores the relevant knowledge and information used by the inference engine.

nodes.name: Rule Base
nodes.description: The part of the knowledge base in an expert system that contains the rules used by the inference engine.

nodes.name: Fuzzy Logic
nodes.description: A mathematical approach that deals with uncertainty and imprecision by assigning degrees of membership to variables.

nodes.name: Knowledge Acquisition
nodes.description: The process of gathering, organizing, and inputting knowledge into the knowledge base of an expert system.

nodes.name: Explanation Facility
nodes.description: The component of an expert system that provides explanations and justification for the system's conclusions and reasoning.

nodes.name: Logic-based Knowledge Representation
nodes.description: Representation of knowledge using logical formalisms, such as first-order logic or description logic.

nodes.name: Semantic Networks
nodes.description: Graph-based representation of knowledge, where nodes represent concepts and edges represent relationships between them.

nodes.name: Frame-based Representation
nodes.description: Representation of knowledge using frames or schema, which capture the structure and properties of objects or concepts.

nodes.name: Ontologies
nodes.description: Formal representation of knowledge that consists of a set of concepts, relationships, and axioms used to model a domain.

nodes.name: Probabilistic Knowledge Representation
nodes.description: Representation of uncertainty and probabilistic information in knowledge representation systems.

nodes.name: Computer Vision
nodes.description: Computer vision is the field of study that focuses on teaching computers to see and understand visual data.

nodes.name: Machine Learning
nodes.description: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that focuses on developing algorithms and models that allow computers to learn and make predictions from data.

nodes.name: Control Systems
nodes.description: Control systems involve the design and analysis of systems that continuously monitor and adjust the behavior of physical systems.

nodes.name: Artificial Intelligence
nodes.description: Artificial intelligence is the development of computer systems that can perform tasks that would normally require human intelligence.

nodes.name: Motion Planning
nodes.description: Motion planning is the process of determining a sequence of valid and collision-free movements for a robot to navigate from its current state to a desired goal state.

nodes.name: Sensors
nodes.description: Sensors are devices that measure physical properties, such as distance, temperature, or pressure, and provide data to a robot for perception and interaction with its environment.

nodes.name: Kinematics
nodes.description: Kinematics is the study of motion without considering the forces that cause the motion.

nodes.name: Localization and Mapping
nodes.description: Localization and mapping involve determining the position and orientation of a robot in its environment, as well as creating maps of the environment based on sensor data.

nodes.name: Robot Hardware
nodes.description: Robot hardware refers to the physical components and systems that make up a robot, such as actuators, sensors, and structures.

nodes.name: Human-Robot Interaction
nodes.description: Human-robot interaction is the study of how humans and robots can interact and communicate with each other, including aspects such as speech recognition, gesture recognition, and natural language processing.

nodes.name: Classification
nodes.description: Supervised learning technique that assigns an individual to a discrete class or label based on its features.

nodes.name: Regression
nodes.description: Supervised learning technique used to predict continuous or numerical values based on input features.

nodes.name: Decision Trees
nodes.description: Supervised learning algorithm that partitions data into segments using a hierarchy of if-else conditions.

nodes.name: Random Forest
nodes.description: Ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees to improve prediction accuracy and reduce overfitting.

nodes.name: Naive Bayes
nodes.description: Probabilistic classification algorithm based on Bayes' theorem and the assumption of independence between features.

nodes.name: K-nearest Neighbors
nodes.description: Supervised learning algorithm that classifies examples based on their similarity to k-nearest neighbors in the training data.

nodes.name: Support Vector Machines
nodes.description: Supervised learning model that finds the best hyperplane to separate different classes by maximizing the margin.

nodes.name: Neural Networks
nodes.description: Connectionist models loosely inspired by the human brain, used to approximate functions or classify data.

nodes.name: Ensemble Learning
nodes.description: Technique that combines multiple individual models to improve overall prediction performance.

nodes.name: Evaluation Metrics
nodes.description: Measures used to evaluate the performance of supervised learning models, such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

nodes.name: Clustering algorithms
nodes.description: Algorithms that group data points based on their similarity.

nodes.name: Dimensionality reduction
nodes.description: Techniques that reduce the number of features in a dataset.

nodes.name: Anomaly detection
nodes.description: Methods that identify unusual patterns or outliers in data.

nodes.name: Association rule mining
nodes.description: Techniques that discover interesting relationships between variables in large datasets.

nodes.name: Self-organizing maps
nodes.description: Neural network algorithms for visualizing high-dimensional data in two or three dimensions.

nodes.name: Labelled Data
nodes.description: Data points that have been manually labeled with the correct output

nodes.name: Unlabelled Data
nodes.description: Data points that have not been labeled with the correct output

nodes.name: Training Data
nodes.description: Data points used to train a machine learning model

nodes.name: Validation Data
nodes.description: Data points used to validate and tune a machine learning model

nodes.name: Classifiers
nodes.description: Algorithms that assign labels or classify data points into distinct classes

nodes.name: Value Function
nodes.description: The value function in reinforcement learning represents the long-term expected reward at each state of the environment.

nodes.name: Policy
nodes.description: The policy in reinforcement learning is a mapping from states to actions, which determines the agent's behavior in the environment.

nodes.name: Reward Function
nodes.description: The reward function in reinforcement learning defines the immediate feedback or reinforcement the agent receives based on its actions.

nodes.name: Q-Learning
nodes.description: Q-Learning is a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm that learns an optimal action-value function for an agent in an environment.

nodes.name: State
nodes.description: The state in reinforcement learning represents the current condition or configuration of the environment where the agent is situated.

nodes.name: Action
nodes.description: An action in reinforcement learning represents the choices or decisions that an agent can take in a particular state of the environment.

nodes.name: Markov Decision Process (MDP)
nodes.description: A Markov Decision Process is a mathematical framework used to model decision-making in situations where outcomes are partly random and partly under control of the decision maker.

nodes.name: Exploration-Exploitation Tradeoff
nodes.description: The exploration-exploitation tradeoff in reinforcement learning refers to the dilemma of choosing between known actions that yield high rewards (exploitation) and exploring new actions to gather more information (exploration).

nodes.name: Neural Networks
nodes.description: A subfield of machine learning that is inspired by the structure and function of the brain. It consists of a collection of interconnected processing nodes called artificial neurons or nodes.

nodes.name: Backpropagation
nodes.description: A technique used in training neural networks. It involves calculating the gradient of the loss function with respect to the weights and biases of the network and using this gradient to update the parameters via gradient descent.

nodes.name: Convolutional Neural Networks
nodes.description: A type of neural network specifically designed for processing structured grid-like data, such as images. It applies convolutional filters to the input data to detect relevant features and uses pooling to reduce the spatial dimensions.

nodes.name: Recurrent Neural Networks
nodes.description: A type of neural network that is capable of processing sequential data by maintaining a hidden state that captures information from previous inputs. It is commonly used in tasks such as language modeling and speech recognition.

nodes.name: Generative Adversarial Networks
nodes.description: A class of machine learning algorithms where two neural networks, a generator and a discriminator, are pitted against each other in a game-theoretic framework. The generator learns to generate synthetic samples that resemble real data, while the discriminator learns to distinguish between real and fake samples.

nodes.name: Activation Function
nodes.description: A function that determines the output of a neural network node

nodes.name: Backpropagation
nodes.description: A method used in neural networks to update the weights of the network

nodes.name: Gradient Descent
nodes.description: An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function in a neural network

nodes.name: Deep Learning
nodes.description: A subfield of machine learning that focuses on neural networks with multiple layers

nodes.name: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)
nodes.description: A type of neural network specifically designed for image recognition tasks

nodes.name: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)
nodes.description: A type of neural network that can process sequential data

nodes.name: Convolutional layers
nodes.description: Layers in a Convolutional Neural Network that perform the convolution operation, extracting feature maps from input data.

nodes.name: Pooling layers
nodes.description: Layers in a Convolutional Neural Network that reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps, summarizing the presence of features.

nodes.name: Fully connected layers
nodes.description: Layers in a Convolutional Neural Network that connect every neuron from the previous layer to the subsequent layer.

nodes.name: Activation functions
nodes.description: Functions applied to the output of neurons, adding non-linearity to the network and enabling complex mappings.

nodes.name: Loss functions
nodes.description: Functions that quantify the discrepancy between predicted and actual values, guiding the optimization of the network.

nodes.name: Gradient descent
nodes.description: Optimization algorithm used to train Convolutional Neural Networks by iteratively adjusting the network parameters to minimize the loss function.

nodes.name: Image preprocessing
nodes.description: Techniques applied to input images, such as normalization or augmentation, to improve the performance and generalization of the network.

nodes.name: Transfer learning
nodes.description: Technique where pre-trained Convolutional Neural Networks are used as a starting point for a new task, enabling faster and more accurate training.

nodes.name: Data augmentation
nodes.description: Technique that increases the diversity of the training data by applying random transformations, improving the network's ability to generalize.

nodes.name: Hyperparameter tuning
nodes.description: Process of finding the optimal configuration of hyperparameters for a Convolutional Neural Network, typically done through experimentation.
